text: Hi Manvir! Great to e-meet you! :smile:

here's a little bit about me: I'm Stefi, I live in London but I am from Greece and I studied Business Management as a Bachelor degree when starting out uni. Then I realised I was more interested in people and how they work and what makes them tick, so I decided to study Business Psychology as a Masters and then pursued a course on Life Coaching and recently I started being self employed as a Personal Development Coach where I am helping people go past any limitations they have, to achieve their goals and improve their relationships with others either personally or professionally.
I would be happy to learn more about you, what your concerns are and things you'd like to have a chat about :smile:

Heyy nice to meet you!:wave::wave: So iâ€™m in year 13 now and im stressed about my personal statement, like i dont understand how i would start it or what to write in it. Also i want to study psychology at uni but im not sure if i would like it or not, im very intrested in how people work psychologically. So i wanted some advice on what to expect if i did study psychology.

Also i feel like im very behind compared to my peers, everyone already knows what there doing at uni and im still so indecisive. Originally i wanted to do psychiatry but changed my mind to do a psychology degree at uni and then study forensic psychology and pursue in that. I also wanted to do forensic science but im not even sure what i want to study at uni

Being indecisive in this stage is very normal.. Not everyone knows what they want to do for sure at this age (including myself :smile: ) but that's alright.. all you need is time to figure things out slowly slowly.. Even if people seem like they have decided and are sure, you never know how things might change later on because people discover what they like more as they grow and learn more about themselves... So all of this is totally fine :smiley:

But if we take into consideration the interests you have at the moment, you seem to be intrigued by psychology whether it is forensic or psychiatry.. So one of the ideas you have at the moment is to study psychology in general as a Bachelor and then specialise in Forensic psychology after that?

If you do study psychology as a Bachelor's degree, it's a 3 year course that you will get to learn more in general how the brain works, human behaviours, social and developmental psychology, clinical and cognitive aspects as well... and after that you would have the option to specialise in a specific field out of many that exist... (forensic, child, clinical, health..etc)
after that you could either work for an organisation (depending on which field you would choose) or have your own practice
Is there a specific reason you are more drawn in the forensic psychology?

I find forensic psychology very intresting and ive always wanted to do something linked with forensics. At first i wanted to do forensic science but then changed my mind and decided i wanted to do forensic psychology, and thats becuause i do find the minds of criminals unusual but not in a bad way. Also yeaah im planning on doing a psychology as a bachelors degree and then work in the forensic field.
But yeah like you said i need time to figure what i actually want to do, because i tend to change my mind a lot and if i rush into something then i could regret it in the future
Uni is also stressing me out and i havent even started yet. So if i do choose psychology im not sure what uni to even apply to, what uni did u study at?

Im guessing you moved out for uni? Correct me if im wrong but how was the whole uni experience? And also is it too late to change my mind even if i wanted to do another course, right now all that i think i would intrested in is psychology

when you say you tend to change your mind a lot, between which subjects are you changing towards..? what else comes to your mind as all subjects when thinking about what to do? apart from the forensic science/psychology
Yes I was living in Greece and then moved to the UK to study
I studied my Bachelor at Kingston Uni and and Masters at University of East London

well, the whole uni experience was interesting, the faculties do give a lot of support to students in regards to almost everything.. But what I do found to play a significant role was the tutors.. If they were really interested in the class and the students, usually their modules were really enjoyable, but if not, you had to do most of the work individually.. but I guess that's everywhere.. In terms of difficulty, I would say it is not great if you are interested in the subjects because then you have the drive to learn and study about them, and then through the groups and assignments (which are usually very well explained and there is support) you would get just fine.. What is it specifically you are concerned about uni?

If your main interest is in psychology, you can follow this and go with the course.. As far as I'm concerned, you can change course before the first semester starts so even if they have accepted you before that and you change your mind, you could apply for another one. Or if you are during the course, in the next year you could also change

I changed my mind between any psychology related topic and teaching like becoming a teacher, but im not as passionate about that then i am with psychology. But teaching is like 3rd on my list, i was having a hard time choosing what i would want to do because i had to also think long term as well. Im sure i wouldnt want to do teaching my whole life.

The thing that im most scared about in uni is the change to be honest. I expect university to be way more larger then the sixth form i go to now obviously, and also the lessons in terms of the change of scene and how independent we have to be when it comes to our work. Also going to university i dont know what to expect which can be kind of intimidating, i have a idea of what unis i want to go to but not 100% sure.
Ive also heard that the psychology field is very competitive nowadays which is also something i need to keep in mind, but then again i know a lot of fields are competitive nowadays
